Another year, another shooting of an unarmed black man by a Tulsa police officer, another protest.

“We could not just sit down and see this happen once again in our city and not say anything,” said Marq Lewis, founder of We The People Oklahoma.

The activist group led calls for change when Robert Bates killed Eric Harris last year and channelled community anger again on Tuesday as about 300 people gathered peacefully to demand the firing and prosecution of Betty Shelby, a white Tulsa city police officer who shot Terence Crutcher dead last Friday.

What on the face of it should have been a routine event – an officer responding to a report of a broken-down vehicle – went rapidly and horrifically askew, a death recorded on graphic video that pinged around the planet on social media and was cited by everybody from local protesters to a presidential candidate
as yet more evidence of the intersection of systemic racism and police brutality.

“It’s just sad – but we need accountability,” Lewis said before he addressed a chanting crowd that crammed on to the steps outside the downtown police headquarters, a towel perched on his right shoulder so he could wipe away the sweat that dripped as he spoke on a sweltering evening in the state’s second-biggest city.

Related: Tulsa officers 'don't want this case to be about race', Eric Harris family says

After a year of pressure, We The People saw a rare outcome earlier this year in the case of Bates, a “pay to play” volunteer Tulsa County sheriff’s deputy who shot dead Harris, an African American man, during a sting operation in 2015.

“He shot me!” Harris cries in video footage. “Oh my God, I’m losing my breath.” In an hour he would be dead. “Fuck your breath,” one of the officers replies.

Then aged 73, Bates was a friend of the sheriff, Stanley Glanz, and had made large donations to the department. The former insurance executive said that he meant to use a Taser but reached for his gun by mistake. He was convicted of manslaughter last April and sentenced to four years in prison. Glanz resigned last year.

The results were a major victory for Lewis and his fellow activists, given how rarely officers who discharge their weapons are charged with a crime, let alone convicted. But with Bates only four months into his sentence, Tulsa is again in the national spotlight because of a single bullet fired at an unarmed man.

Shelby, 42, a five-year veteran of the department who was previously with the sheriff’s office, arrived to find an apparently abandoned SUV in the middle of a two-lane road six miles north-east of downtown Tulsa at about 7.45pm last Friday.

Dashcam video shows Crutcher walking away from Shelby towards the left side of his SUV with his hands in the air as three more officers arrive and approach. Their presence blocks the camera’s view of the 40-year-old as, almost simultaneously, Shelby shoots him and Tyler Turnbough deploys his Taser. Crutcher is seen slumping to the ground as a woman cries, “Shots fired!”

Related: Video in Tulsa police shooting shows black man was unarmed with hands up

Footage of the moment from a police helicopter circling overhead does not clearly capture Crutcher’s actions when he is shot but includes audio of a conversation between two officers inside. One of them is reportedly Shelby’s husband.

“Well, he’s got his hands up there for her now,” one of the men says as Crutcher moves towards the vehicle.

“Time for Taser, I think,” the other responds.

“Got a feeling that’s about to happen.”

“That looks like a bad dude, too. Could be on something.”

The camera zooms in as Crutcher falls, his white top covered in blood.
Police released the footage on Monday, a day after showing it to Crutcher’s family. Local authorities pledged to conduct a thorough investigation with possible criminal charges. The US justice department opened a federal investigation into whether civil rights violations occurred.

“I’m going to tell you right here now that there was no gun on the suspect or in the suspect’s vehicle,” Chuck Jordan, the Tulsa police chief, told reporters. “I want to assure our community, and I want to assure all of you and people across the nation who are going to be looking at this, we will achieve justice.” Protesters have objected to the characterization of Crutcher as a “suspect”.

Shelby’s lawyer, Scott Wood, said that she had tried to engage with Crutcher for more than a minute before the footage starts but he was erratic, uncommunicative and not following commands, making her think he was on drugs. “She is yelling at him to stop and get on the ground, he refuses to comply with those commands,” Wood told the Guardian.

“She didn’t have a Taser out because she had thought based on his earlier behaviour that he possibly could have a gun. If you think someone could possibly have a gun, you don’t have a Taser out, you have a gun out.”

Shelby fired, Wood said, because “she thought he was an immediate threat to her life” when “he kind of looks back towards her and then starts to reach into – through the window – and that’s what caused her to react and fire her one round.”

However, at a press conference on Tuesday, one ofthe Crutcher family’s lawyers, Benjamin Crump, said that stills from the video showing the man’s blood on the driver’s-side window prove that it was up – so Crutcher could not have reached inside and potentially led police to think he was going for a weapon.

The Tulsa World newspaper reported that police said a vial of PCP, a hallucinogen, was found in the vehicle after the shooting. Crutcher family allies said this was an attempt to smear him and deflect attention from the officers’ conduct. “Let us not be thrown a red herring and to say because something was found in the car that is justification to shoot him,” Crump told reporters.

The family wants Shelby, who is on administrative leave, to face criminal charges. Lewis said he will meet with Jordan on Wednesday and agitate for her arrest and for better community policing.

“You all want to know who that ‘big bad dude’ was? That big bad dude was my twin brother,” Crutcher’s sister, Tiffany, said in a press conference. “That big bad dude was a father [of four]. That big bad dude was a son. That big bad dude was enrolled at Tulsa Community College, just wanting to make us proud. That big bad dude loved God. That big bad dude was at church singing, with all of his flaws, every week. That big bad dude, that’s who he was.”

Arlando Jasper heard the news on Saturday, his 36th birthday. It is 15 years since he first met Crutcher in a chance encounter on the street. “He saw me and said: ‘God told me to take you wherever you want to go.’ I didn’t even know the man, but there was something about him that made me comfortable. He just offered me a lift, he took me all the way from north Tulsa to south Tulsa … and he didn’t know who I was,” said Jasper, a pastor. They kept in contact.

Crutcher came from a family of gospel musicians. The last time he saw Jasper, a couple of months ago, he suggested they get together and create some gospel tracks. “He’s the kind of person that always wanted you laughing, he’s a jokester to his heart, when people are around him he’s going to make sure everybody’s having a good time. He’s not having a good time unless everybody else is. Man, he’s just a good person, period, and you can’t lie to me about him ’cause I know him personally,” Jasper said.

Race relations have long been uneasy in Tulsa. Some at Tuesday’s demonstration referred to the lingering effects of the race riot of 1921, which saw as many as 300 people killed as the city’s relatively prosperous African American neighbourhood was wrecked.

Six years ago the city opened Reconciliation Park to commemorate the riot. It includes a statue of a black man with his arms raised in surrender. Some 95 years on from the terrible violence, several protesters on Tuesday wore T-shirts with the slogan “Hands up, don’t shoot”, and lamented that though Crutcher held his arms aloft, the submissive gesture did not save his life in 2016.

“I just dropped my aunt off, and I had to wonder,” Jasper said. “I wasn’t worried about whether or not I was going to get shot in the ’hood, whether I was going to get robbed; I had to wonder whether or not the police were going to pull me over and do something to me.”

Protesters clash with police in Charlotte

Twelve police officers were injured in overnight disturbances in Charlotte, North Carolina, after protesters clashed with police following the fatal police shooting of a black man earlier in the day. Keith Scott, 43, was shot and killed by Charlotte-Mecklenburg officer Brentley Vinson, who is also black, after being mistaken for a wanted man. Police say Scott, a father of seven, brandished a gun as he got out of a car; his family insist he was sitting in his car reading a book and had no gun. In a video posted to Facebook Live, Scott’s daughter Lyric can be heard yelling at investigators not to plant a weapon in Scott’s car. “Because that’s what the fuck y’all do,” she said. As protests swelled, police used teargas in an attempt to disperse crowds heard yelling “Black lives matter,” and “Hands up, don’t shoot!” One person held up a sign saying “Stop killing us”; another sign said: “It was a book”.

US accuses Russia of UN Syria bombing

US defense officials now believe that Russian planes dropped the bombs that destroyed a UN aid convoy and killed at least 20 people on Monday, the Guardian has learned. The claim of direct Russian involvement in the bombing, if confirmed, would have far-reaching consequences. Earlier on Tuesday, UN secretary general Ban Ki-moon used his farewell address to the UN general assembly to denounce the strike as a “sickening, savage and apparently deliberate attack”, describing the bombers at “cowards”, and UN officials have said it is a potential war crime. The convoy attack is a “new low”, says the Guardian in an editorial.

How would Trump really go about seizing Iraq’s oil?

Republican nominee Donald Trump has said it is part of his national security strategy to “take the oil” in Iraq and from areas controlled by Islamic State extremists to reimburse the US for the costs of its military commitments in the region. “You’re not stealing anything,” he said earlier this month. But, writes world affairs editor Julian Borger, this presents huge problems from almost every angle, according to military, strategic, legal and oil experts. “First of all, there are issues of principle and legality. Trump’s frequent invocation of the ‘spoils of war’ seems to hark back to a bygone age of conquistadors and plunder-based imperialism, illegal now under the laws of war.” It would take close to 100,000 troops to hold the oil fields and extract the oil, one expert suggests.

Chinese space station to crash

Chinese authorities have confirmed that their eight-tonne ‘Heavenly Palace’ space station will re-enter the atmosphere sometime in 2017 with some parts likely to hit Earth. The Tiangong-1 or “Heavenly Palace” lab was described as a “potent political symbol” of China’s growing power when it was launched in 2011. Officials now say the lab has “comprehensively fulfilled its historical mission”. Where and when it will crash is unknown. “You really can’t steer these things,” says Harvard astrophysicist Jonathan McDowell. “Not knowing when it’s going to come down translates as not knowing where it’s going to come down.”

Cities to crackdown on unsanctioned surveillance

Local officials in 11 cities around the US launched a campaign on Wednesday to crack down on the unsanctioned police use of surveillance equipment, especially devices that imitate cellphone towers. Cell-site simulators, such as Harris Corporation’s Stingray device or Digital Receiver Technology’s (DRT) Dirtbox, fool cellphones into treating them like cell towers can be used to scoop up data from all devices that connect to the fake tower.

Protesters took to the streets in Charlotte, North Carolina, on Tuesday night, clashing with police after the fatal police shooting of a black man earlier in the day.

Keith Scott, 43, was shot and killed by Charlotte-Mecklenburg officer Brentley Vinson, who is also black, after being mistaken for a wanted man.

Related: Video in Tulsa police shooting shows black man was unarmed with hands up

Police said officers went to a Charlotte apartment complex around 4pm looking for a suspect with an outstanding warrant when they encountered Scott, who was not the suspect they were looking for, inside a car.

According to department spokesman Keith Trietley, officers saw the man get out of the car with a gun and then get back in. When officers approached the car, the man got out of the car with the gun again. At that point, officers deemed the man a threat and at least one fired a weapon, he said. A weapon was recovered by detectives at the scene.

According to police, officers immediately began rendering aid after the shots were fired. Scott, a father of seven, was pronounced dead at Carolinas Medical Center.

The police version is at odds with that of Scott’s family who have insisted that he was disabled, sitting in his car reading a book, and had no gun. “He sits in the shade, reads his book and waits on his kid to get off the bus,” Scott’s sister told reporters. “He didn’t have no gun, he wasn’t messing with nobody.”

In a video posted to Facebook Live from the scene, Scott’s daughter Lyric can be heard yelling at investigators on the scene not to plant a weapon in Scott’s car. “Because that’s what the fuck y’all do,” she said.

As protests swelled on Tuesday night, police used teargas in an attempt to disperse crowds heard yelling “Black lives matter” and “Hands up, don’t shoot!” One person held up a sign saying “Stop killing us”; another sign said: “It was a book”.

In statements, the Charlotte-Mecklenburg police department distinguished between “agitators” and “demonstrators”, blaming the former for damaging police vehicles and causing injuries to at least a dozen officers. One officer was reportedly struck in the face with a rock.

Charlotte mayor Jennifer Roberts tweeted on Tuesday night: “I will continue to work with our manager & Chief on officer involved shooting. We are reaching out to community to ask for calm.”

Police blocked access to the area, which is about a mile from the campus of the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, as protesters gathered after the shooting.
Video from WCCB-TV in Charlotte showed police in riot gear stretched across a two-lane road confronting protesters at the apartment complex later in the night. Some of the officers flanked the main line on one side of the road.

The shooting comes quickly on the heels of the death of Terence Crutcher, an unarmed black man shot by police in Tulsa, Oklahoma. Both incidents are just the latest in a summer that has been fraught with tensions between police and black and activist communities outraged by police killings of black people.

Officer Vinson, who has been with the department for two years, has been placed on paid administrative leave, which is standard procedure in such cases.
